title: 110_s3184
content:
The Act may be cited as the "Empowering Teaching and Learning Through Education Portals Act". The Act, known as the "Empowering Teaching and Learning Through Education Portals Act," defines "21st century skills" as essential skills for students to succeed in school, work, and life. These skills include core academic subjects, learning and innovation skills like creativity and critical thinking, and life and career skills for the global economy. The "Empowering Teaching and Learning Through Education Portals Act" defines "21st century skills" as essential for student success in school, work, and life. These skills include flexibility, adaptability, productivity, accountability, leadership, and responsibility. Core academic subjects and educational terms are also defined in the Act. The "Empowering Teaching and Learning Through Education Portals Act" defines key terms such as covered school, covered student, covered teacher, education technology, and institution of higher education. These terms are crucial for understanding the Act's provisions related to improving student learning and teacher training. The term "institution of higher education" is defined as per the Higher Education Act of 1965. "Professional development" refers to training that enhances a teacher's skills and positively impacts student learning. The term "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of Education. SEC. 3. GRANTS. The Secretary may award grants to eligible States for education portal initiatives, with a 50 percent Federal share. States can provide the non-Federal share in cash or in kind. Grants can be awarded for 1 to 3 years. SEC. 4. APPLICATIONS AND AWARDS. To be eligible for a grant under this section, a State must submit an application to the Secretary with a comprehensive plan for the initiative, details on providing the non-Federal share of costs, meeting maintenance of effort requirements, and outlining the protocol to be used. The State must provide information on ensuring safe access to the education portal, establish an advisory panel, and plan for sufficient bandwidth capacity. The Secretary will consider previous implementation of the education portal initiative when awarding grants. The State's previous implementation of the education portal initiative will be considered when awarding grants, without penalizing States that have made greater progress in developing such initiatives. SEC. 5. USE OF FUNDS. A State receiving a grant under this Act must use the funds to implement an education portal initiative, including providing high-quality resources for educators, students, and parents aligned with State standards, as well as professional development for educators. The State may use grant funds for an education portal initiative that provides resources for educators, including formative assessment tools and information on effective classroom practices. The education portal initiative offers access to various educational resources, technology-based curriculum tools, lesson plans, and a support network for educators to collaborate and communicate. It also includes digital media content developed by a television public broadcasting entity. The education portal initiative provides access to resources for educators, students, and parents in the State, allowing them to contribute and access information statewide. The education portal initiative in the State allows access for educators, students, and parents statewide, subject to protocol. Federal funds from the Elementary and Secondary Education Act can be used to maintain the portal after the funding period ends. A conforming amendment is made to the Act. SEC. 6. MAINTENANCE OF EFFORT.

A State receiving a grant must maintain education portal initiative expenditures at or above the previous fiscal year's level. If expenditures fall below, the grant for the following year will be reduced by the shortfall.

SEC. 7. EVALUATIONS AND CONFERENCE. SEC. 7. EVALUATIONS AND CONFERENCE. The Secretary will evaluate initiatives funded under the Act and report to Congress. A conference will be held every 2 years to share best practices. States receiving grants must conduct evaluations and submit reports to the Secretary. SEC. 8. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS. Authorization of appropriations for the Act is set at $100,000,000 for fiscal years 2009 through 2012, with additional funding as needed for the following 2 years. Special rules are established for corporate charitable contributions to education portal projects of eligible states. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to include a special rule for corporate contributions to education portal projects of eligible states. This rule applies separately to these contributions compared to other charitable contributions of the taxpayer. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 has a special rule for corporate contributions to education portal projects of eligible states, where a qualified education portal project contribution involves substituting '50 percent' for '10 percent' in certain cases. The amendments made by this section apply to contributions made after the enactment of this Act for education portal initiatives.
